description: {"blocks":[{"key":"6ck2m","text":"This protocol describes in great detail all the steps that must be taken for strontium isotope analysis on archaeological cremated remains, from the receipt of the samples to the deposition of the data generated by Thermal Ionisation Mass Spectrometry (TIMS). ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

references.title: The IsoArcH initiative: Working towards an open and collaborative isotope data culture in bioarchaeology.
references.authors: Plomp E, Stantis C, James HF, Cheung C, Snoeck C, Kootker L, Kharobi A, Borges C, Moreiras Reynaga DK, Pospieszny Ł, Fulminante F, Stevens R, Alaica AK, Becker A, de Rochefort X, Salesse K

references.title: The Relevance of Sr–O–C Isotope Analysis on Burnt Human Skeletal Remains in Archeological and Forensic Contexts: A Review and Future Directions
references.authors: Maura De Coster, Saskia Ammer, Tim Laning, Lisette M. Kootker

references.title: Strontium isotope analysis on cremated human remains from Stonehenge support links with west Wales.
references.authors: Snoeck C, Pouncett J, Claeys P, Goderis S, Mattielli N, Parker Pearson M, Willis C, Zazzo A, Lee-Thorp JA, Schulting RJ

references.title: Calcined bone provides a reliable substrate for strontium isotope ratios as shown by an enrichment experiment.
references.authors: Snoeck C, Lee-Thorp J, Schulting R, de Jong J, Debouge W, Mattielli N

related_materials.name: Acetic acid (glacial 100%, Suprapur for trace analysis, Supelco)

status.info: We use this protocol and it is working

steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"7bfa4","text":"Mechanically clean the cremated bone samples using a handheld drill (e.g., PROXXON or Dremel) to remove the outer layer of the bone, so all soil residue is removed. If present, also remove all of the trabecular bone (but see De Coster et al. 2024 paragraph 4.1).  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"21q98","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"26ogt","text":"Next, following the protocol described in Snoeck et al., 2015,2018  transfer the cleaned bone fragments to glass vials and leach them with circa  (10:1 ratio)    ultrasonically for  -  , followed by two Milli-Q‱ rinses, and a   Milli-Q‱ ultrasonic wash. Repeat these steps until the Milli-Q‱ in the glass vials are clear or show a white cloudy color. Dry the samples on a hotplate at    . {"blocks":[{"key":"82sg9","text":"After drying the samples on the hotplates the samples, subsample ca.    using a handheld drill (e.g., PROXXON or Dremel) equipped with a diamond tipped ball burr. The bone should be fully white after the mechanical cleaning. Any grey or black bones are not suitable for Sr isotope analysis. Therefore, exclude the discolored samples from further analysis. However, if only parts of the bone are not fully calcined/white, specifically target the white surfaces. {"blocks":[{"key":"1vol","text":"Weigh    of cremated bone powder into an acid-cleaned Eppendorf® centrifuge tube. Note down the weights in gram. Next, add   of pro-analysis quality 3M HNO3. Bone powder will dissolve within seconds in  . If small fragments of bone are sampled, place the Eppendorf® tube in an ultrasonic bath for ca.   to allow all enamel to dissolve. Next, centrifuge the samples for   at  . {"blocks":[{"key":"37ln5","text":"Separate Sr from the matrix using in-house made Sr columns made from 1.5 ml pipette tips and using a 3.5 mm PE frit (Angst and Pfister, h = 2 mm, porosity 35 μm). ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2prk","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9mk1b","text":"The columns are stored in pipette tip boxes in ±3M HCl. Take out a column with a plastic tweezer, tap the HCL out of the pipette tip and rinse 3 times with Milli-Q. Place the column in the rack and carefully fill with Milli-Q. Add   Sr resin ( in slurry (0.2M HNO3), Eichrom Technologies, 100–150 μm mesh). The remaining 100 µl can be used for concentration measurements. Use a new, acid-cleaned pipette tip for every sample (see 4.2). Once the samples dripped through the columns, wash the samples twice with   3M HNO3. Replace the waste beakers containing the pre-fraction with acid-cleaned 5 or 7 ml PFA (Savillex) beakers (see 4.1). To elute the Sr, wash with   Milli-Q.  Add 0.07 to 0.11 gram (1-3 drops) of 84Sr spike to the blank(s). Add 1 drop 0.5% H3PO4 to the samples (and blanks and in-house standard if applicable).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sub","offset":235,"length":1},{"style":"sub","offset":475,"length":1},{"style":"sub","offset":478,"length":1},{"style":"sup","offset":430,"length":2}],"entityRanges":[{"key":4,"offset":11,"length":1},{"key":5,"offset":227,"length":1},{"key":6,"offset":381,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"ffoji","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bglnl","text":"Close the beakers and transfer them to a hotplate. {"blocks":[{"key":"b8911","text":"Add   10% HNO3 to the dried samples. Place the outgassed single annealed rhenium filaments in the dedicated holders and increase the current to 1.5 mA. Create little 'dams' with parafilm. Reduce the current to 0 mA. Pipette   of TaCl5 and   of sample (50%, to allow for a rerun if needed) between the parafilm dams on the filament. Dry slowly at 1.0 mA. Once dry, gradually increase the current to 1.3 mA until the samples turn black, then to 1.6 mA to burn away the parafilm. Increase further to approximately 1.8-2.0 mA until the samples glow. Once they are bright red, immediately reduce the current to 0 mA and load the sample onto the turret. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sub","offset":13,"length":2},{"style":"sub","offset":233,"length":2}],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":4,"length":1},{"key":1,"offset":224,"length":1},{"key":2,"offset":239,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"22eaa","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9k073","text":"Use a new, acid-cleaned pipette tip (see 4.2)  for every sample. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"amount","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"amount":"2","error":false,"guid":"79DB3B692EEA11EFB98B0A58A9FEAC02","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"unit":1}},"1":{"type":"amount","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"amount":"2","error":false,"guid":"79DB3BEF2EEA11EFB98B0A58A9FEAC02","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"unit":1}},"2":{"type":"amount","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"amount":"1","error":false,"guid":"79DB3C672EEA11EFB98B0A58A9FEAC02","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"unit":1}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"9j6be","text":"Upload the 87Sr/86Sr data as a dataset on IsoArch.eu. IsoArcH is an open and collaborative database of georeferenced isotopic measures of bioarcheological samples from all time periods and all around the world. The IsoArcH initiative supports the CARE principles. In parallel, IsoArcH has adopted the FAIR practices to ensure that datasets are readily discoverable and compatible within the IsoArcH database.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sup","offset":11,"length":2},{"style":"sup","offset":16,"length":2}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6qdiv","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"2o2no","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bpqr","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"8kqe4","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"dataset","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"affiliation":null,"can_edit":true,"guid":"B3C65DAC2D8E11EFB4BA0A58A9FEAC02","link":"isoarch.eu","name":"IsoArcH"}},"1":{"type":"citation","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"align":"","authors":"Plomp E, Stantis C, James HF, Cheung C, Snoeck C, Kootker L, Kharobi A, Borges C, Moreiras Reynaga DK, Pospieszny Ł, Fulminante F, Stevens R, Alaica AK, Becker A, de Rochefort X, Salesse K","can_edit":true,"created_on":"","date":1663113600,"doi":"https://doi.org/10.1016/j.dib.2022.108595","guid":"29C7DC2AFE3C451AA6A6722A2D2BDA60","id":0,"journal":"","protocol_guid":"","protocol_id":0,"title":"The IsoArcH initiative: Working towards an open and collaborative isotope data culture in bioarchaeology."}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"6pefb","text":"Cleaning Teflon® PFA (high-purity Perfluoroalkoxy resin) laboratory equipment: sub-boil in pro-analysis quality 3M HNO3 and 6-7M HCl for 2 hours each in a fume cupboard. Rinse 3 times with Milli-Q between the baths. Add ca. 3 ml 6-7M HCl, close the caps and leave on a hotplate at   for 2-5 days. Discard the acid, rinse 2 times with Milli-Q and store in a clean box. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sub","offset":118,"length":1}],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":281,"length":1}],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"temperature","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"error_temperature":false,"guid":"19AE5E522EEB11EFB98B0A58A9FEAC02","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"temperature":"120","unit":10}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"50dqn","text":"Cleaning pipette tips: Fill a pipette box with pipette tips, leaving one slot empty. Fill the box with 500 ml of approximately 3M HCl and let it stand for about 5-10 days at   . Remove the acid and rinse three times with Milli-Q. Place on a hotplate at   to dry. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":174,"length":1},{"key":1,"offset":253,"length":1}],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"temperature","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"error_temperature":false,"guid":"27383DFE2EEB11EFB98B0A58A9FEAC02","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"temperature":"","unit":32}},"1":{"type":"temperature","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"error_temperature":false,"guid":"27383E612EEB11EFB98B0A58A9FEAC02","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"temperature":"60","unit":10}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"cd6gb","text":"If Pars petrosae were sampled, cut them midmodiolarly using a Buehler IsoMet 1000 precision saw (Veselka et al. 2021). Locate the otic capsule and subsample in acid-cleaned Eppendorf‱ tubes approximately   of bone powder with a handheld drill (e.g., PROXXON or Dremel) and transfer the samples to a clean laboratory. Here, follow the protocol described in step 1.
